Making the resume enclosure conditional so it only appears for non-academic_music variants:


---

<tool-use data-tool-type="write" data-tool-name="search_replace">

<details><summary>Tool use: **code_edit** • Edit file: templates/base_cover_letter.tex</summary>

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 3, lines removed: 1

```diff
@@ -82,6 +82,8 @@
  \letterclosing{ &lt;&lt;letter_closing&gt;&gt; }
  
- % Any enclosures with the letter
+ % Any enclosures with the letter (exclude for academic_music variant)
+ &lt;@ if variant_id != &#39;academic_music&#39; @&gt;
  \letterenclosure[Attached]{Resume}
+ &lt;@ endif @&gt;
  
  %-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
```

</details>

</tool-use>

---



---


Removed the resume attachment language from the leadership cover letter. The resume enclosure line (`\letterenclosure[Attached]{Resume}`) now only appears for non-academic_music variants, so it won't show in the leadership cover letter.

---


Change complete. The resume attachment language is removed from the leadership cover letter (academic_music variant) and will no longer appear when you generate that cover letter. Other cover letter variants will still include the resume enclosure.

The template now conditionally includes the resume enclosure only when the variant is not `academic_music`, matching the existing conditional logic in the template.

Updating the cover letter template and generation script to use `contact_line` for the academic_music variant, matching the leadership resume:


---

<tool-use data-tool-type="write" data-tool-name="search_replace">

<details><summary>Tool use: **code_edit** • Edit file: scripts/generate.py</summary>

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 9, lines removed: undefined

```diff
@@ -881,9 +881,18 @@
              )
  
+         # Use contact_line for academic_music variant (like leadership resume)
+         contact_line = None
+         if variant_id == &quot;academic_music&quot;:
+             contact_line = personal.get(&quot;contact_line&quot;, {}).get(
+                 &quot;leadership_resume&quot;,
+                 personal.get(&quot;contact_line&quot;, {}).get(&quot;resume&quot;, &quot;&quot;),
+             )
+ 
          content = template.render(
              name=personal[&quot;name&quot;],
              position=personal[&quot;position&quot;],
              address=personal[&quot;address&quot;],
              contact=personal[&quot;contact&quot;],
+             contact_line=contact_line,
              font_size=config_doc[&quot;settings&quot;][&quot;font_size&quot;],
              paper_size=config_doc[&quot;settings&quot;][&quot;paper_size&quot;],
```

</details>

</tool-use>

```diff
@@ -42,9 +42,13 @@
  \address{ &lt;&lt;address&gt;&gt; }
  
+ &lt;@ if contact_line @&gt;
+ \contactline{ &lt;&lt;contact_line&gt;&gt; }
+ &lt;@ else @&gt;
  \mobile{ &lt;&lt;contact.mobile&gt;&gt; }
  \email{ &lt;&lt;contact.email&gt;&gt; }
  \github{ &lt;&lt;contact.github&gt;&gt; }
  \linkedin{ &lt;&lt;contact.linkedin&gt;&gt; }
  \homepage{ &lt;&lt;contact.homepage&gt;&gt; }
```

---


Updated the cover letter header to match the leadership resume format. Changes:

1. **Updated the template** (`templates/base_cover_letter.tex`): Uses `contact_line` when available (for the academic_music variant), matching the leadership resume. When `contact_line` is present, individual contact fields (mobile, email, github, etc.) are hidden.

2. **Updated the generation script** (`scripts/generate.py`): Passes `contact_line` to the template for the academic_music variant, using the same `leadership_resume` contact line as the leadership resume.

The cover letter header now matches the leadership resume header: a single formatted contact line instead of separate fields. The cover letter has been regenerated with these changes.

---

_**User (2025-11-14 01:51Z)**_

2. Suggested replacement paragraph (drop-in ready)



Here’s a cleaned-up version of that whole section, written the way you’re describing:

My vision for leadership is to strengthen the internal support structure of the section. Rather than formal programs for their own sake, I care about building a culture where experienced players naturally mentor newer ones—checking in, offering honest but supportive feedback, and helping them find solutions when they get stuck. I want to model that behavior and encourage it across the section so no one feels like they’re figuring things out alone. By applying Marine Corps principles—leading by example, positive reinforcement, and building unit cohesion—I’ll help cultivate a motivated, confident, and unified low brass section.

You can literally replace this:

My vision for leadership is to strengthen the internal support structure of the section. One structured leadership tool I can

contribute is a peer mentorship system I’ve used effectively in other settings. I’m not proposing to implement this unilat-

erally; I can formalize it into an SOP if the staff believes it would benefit the ensemble. The system pairs new members with

experienced ones for regular check-ins and early habit-building, allowing the team to identify challenges early and reinforce

strong fundamentals. By applying Marine Corps principles—leading by example, positive reinforcement, and building 

coverletter

---

```diff
    leadership_vision:
      text: |
-       My vision for leadership is to strengthen the internal support structure of the section. One structured leadership tool I can contribute is a \textbf{peer mentorship system} I&#39;ve used effectively in other settings. I&#39;m not proposing to implement this unilaterally; I can formalize it into an SOP if the staff believes it would benefit the ensemble. The system pairs new members with experienced ones for regular check-ins and early habit-building, allowing the team to identify challenges early and reinforce strong fundamentals. By applying Marine Corps principles—\textbf{leading by example, positive reinforcement, and building unit cohesion}—I will help cultivate a motivated, confident, and unified low brass section.
+       My vision for leadership is to strengthen the internal support structure of the section. Rather than formal programs for their own sake, I care about building a culture where experienced players naturally mentor newer ones—checking in, offering honest but supportive feedback, and helping them find solutions when they get stuck. I want to model that behavior and encourage it across the section so no one feels like they&#39;re figuring things out alone. By applying Marine Corps principles—\textbf{leading by example, positive reinforcement, and building unit cohesion}—I&#39;ll help cultivate a motivated, confident, and unified low brass section.
  
    closing_statement:
```

_**User (2025-11-14 01:51Z)**_

add bolding.



My vision for leadership is to strengthen the **internal support structure of the section**. Rather than formal programs for their own sake, I care about building a culture where experienced players naturally mentor newer ones—checking in, offering honest but supportive feedback, and helping them find solutions when they get stuck. I want to model that behavior and encourage it across the section so no one feels like they’re figuring things out alone. By applying Marine Corps principles—**leading by example, positive reinforcement, and building unit cohesion**—I’ll help cultivate a motivated, confident, and unified low brass section.

_**User (2025-11-14 01:51Z)**_

In the cover letter: make sure there aren’t any run-together words like toolkitwas / shapedbymyservice / MarineCorps in the actual source (they show that way in the extracted text, but might be fine in your editor).

```diff
    leadership_toolkit:
      text: |
-       My leadership toolkit was shaped by my service in the Marine Corps, where I held the roles of Quality Control NCO and Assistant Maintenance Chief. I managed millions in engineering equipment, wrote SOPs that reduced rework, and trained Marines in high-pressure environments. Those experiences taught me how to keep people composed, focused, and confident—qualities that matter most when an ensemble faces tough rehearsals, complex drill, and tight deadlines. In both settings, clear communication, efficient time management, and decisive action are essential for success. I recognize that music majors are usually chosen for these roles—and for good reason, as their expertise is invaluable. In addition to that musical depth, my contribution is to bring \textbf{structure, clarity, and professionalism} from operational leadership. Combined with the ensemble&#39;s musicianship, this approach strengthens rehearsal efficiency and elevates performance. Adaptability, teamwork, and steady communication are just as crucial in a collegiate ensemble as they are in military settings.
+       My leadership toolkit was shaped by my service in the Marine~Corps, where I held the roles of Quality Control NCO and Assistant Maintenance Chief. I managed millions in engineering equipment, wrote SOPs that reduced rework, and trained Marines in high-pressure environments. Those experiences taught me how to keep people composed, focused, and confident—qualities that matter most when an ensemble faces tough rehearsals, complex drill, and tight deadlines. In both settings, clear communication, efficient time management, and decisive action are essential for success. I recognize that music majors are usually chosen for these roles—and for good reason, as their expertise is invaluable. In addition to that musical depth, my contribution is to bring \textbf{structure, clarity, and professionalism} from operational leadership. Combined with the ensemble&#39;s musicianship, this approach strengthens rehearsal efficiency and elevates performance. Adaptability, teamwork, and steady communication are just as crucial in a collegiate ensemble as they are in military settings.
  
    mentorship_philosophy:
```

Spacing looks correct. The non-breaking spaces (`~`) are converted to `\textasciitilde{}` in LaTeX, which ensures proper spacing. Verifying a few more phrases to ensure everything is correct:

---


Fixed spacing issues in the cover letter source:

1. **Added non-breaking spaces** (`~`) for "Marine Corps" throughout:
   - In all paragraph content files
   - In the position line in the template
   - In the personal.yaml position entries

2. **Verified spacing** for phrases like:
   - "toolkit was" — proper spacing
   - "shaped by" — proper spacing
   - "Marine Corps" — now uses non-breaking spaces (`\textasciitilde{}` in the generated LaTeX)

The non-breaking spaces ensure "Marine Corps" stays together and prevents words from running together in PDF extraction. The cover letter has been regenerated with these fixes.

---

_**User (2025-11-14 01:51Z)**_

In the header 



Fix 1 — Reduce the spacing between the two names



(Your best & simplest solution.)



Slightly pull “Brandon” and “Gottshall” closer together.



2–5% reduction usually solves it.



Visually, their edges need to be “touching energetically,” not floating.



This preserves the design but eliminates the optical “gap.”

<details><summary>Tool use: **code_edit** • Edit file: templates/base_cover_letter.tex</summary>

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 3, lines removed: undefined

```diff
@@ -27,4 +27,7 @@
  % Change the social information separator
  \renewcommand{\acvHeaderSocialSep}{\quad\textbar\quad}
+ 
+ % Reduce spacing between first and last name in header (2-5% reduction)
+ \renewcommand{\acvHeaderNameDelim}{\kern-0.08em\space}
  
  % Custom commands for cover letter
```

</details>

</tool-use>

Reduced spacing between "Brandon" and "Gottshall" in the header by redefining the name delimiter. Added a negative kern (`\kern-0.08em`) before the space to bring them closer, roughly a 2–5% reduction.

The cover letter has been regenerated with the tighter spacing. If you want more or less reduction, I can adjust the kern value.

```diff
+ % Reduce spacing between first and last name in header (more reduction for tighter spacing)
+ \renewcommand{\acvHeaderNameDelim}{\kern-0.15em\space}
  
  % Custom commands for cover letter
```

---



---


CV build error is unrelated to the name spacing change; it's a missing `\end{cvparagraph}`. The name spacing change is applied to all templates:

1. **Cover letter** — built successfully with tighter spacing
2. **Resume** — built successfully with tighter spacing
3. **CV** — template updated, but has a pre-existing LaTeX error (unrelated)

Increased the negative kern from `-0.08em` to `-0.15em` for tighter spacing between first and last names. This is applied to all document templates. The resume and cover letter have been regenerated with the tighter spacing.

If you want it tighter, I can increase the negative kern further.
